thread.title: West Deptford offense firing on all cylinders
thread.title_full: West Deptford offense firing on all cylinders

title: West Deptford offense firing on all cylinders
text:
More coverage: Southeastern Pa. high school sports 
"I'm seeing week-to-week improvement," West Deptford coach Clyde Folsom said of Hamilton and Dozier. "They're both very skilled with the ability to run well in space and make you miss." 
On a high-powered offense featuring a sturdy front line and burly ballcarriers in senior quarterback Nick Diaco and junior fullback Gio Gismondi, Dozier and Hamilton have made the most of limited opportunities. 
The 6-foot-1, 185-pound Dozier is averaging 19.5 yards per carry with 28 rushes for 547 yards and eight touchdowns. 
Dozier carried the football just four times on Monday night, but shook loose for 118 yards. He scored on runs of 55 and 65 yards. 
"It goes back to practice," Dozier said. "We believe if you practice perfect, you'll play perfect. 
"When we have offensive sessions in practice, we work at it. We're always looking to improve." 
The 5-foot-7, 195-pound Hamilton has 34 carries for 324 yards (9.5-yard average) and six touchdowns. 
Hamilton scored the game's first touchdown Monday night, taking a handoff from Dozier on West Deptford's signature play - the Wing T inside reverse - and racing 67 yards on the Eagles' second play. 
"Our offense is flowing right now," Hamilton said. "It all goes back to how hard we work. We put in the time to be able to play like this in the games." 
Since beating archrival Haddonfield 10-0 in the season opener, West Deptford has scored 234 points in its last four games (58.5-point average). 
"I like where we are right now," said Folsom, whose team has a bye before an Oct. 23 showdown with Colonial Liberty rival Collingswood.
